reviewText:
PANTSU MAY CRY FTMFW YOLOOOOOOO 999999999999/10!!!!!!! but no seriously.

First thing I gotta mention is, there's not really exploration. Just combat. Now if you don't mind being trapped in a circle, it's pretty fun!

I like the fluidity, the movement, and the general ease of stringing moves together and dodging/blocking through things! Graphics and sound are nice, Misa is really elegant and cool as well!

I hope it gets a sequel, and I hope the sequel has some more proper exploration through Japan, though. I wanna explore buildings and fight through the streets and such!

So while it's probably a bit repetitive, if you're a big fan of fast-paced action games and you really like the -action- part, fighting constantly through hordes, this game should be pretty fun for you.

While I certainly wish you weren't so confined, it is a small doujin game and if this game does well hopefully we'll get more, with some better you can actually run around and explore! I don't personally mind, given the price and size of the game but I know there are those of you who would/are turned off by this. Have fun, guys!

Basically, if you have no attention span, read this NOW:  It's a fairly short game. No exploration. You fight in circles. Not many enemys to fight, either.

But if you get it cheap, and you really like DMC and Ninja Gaiden style action games, I think you're in for some fun! Personally, I like those kinds of games a ton. If you also like them a ton, I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Im sorry, I just cant reccomend this game........
Im a big fan of stylish beatemups like this, but it just doesnt seem to do anything well. There's no fluidity between offense and defense, so unless you've rounded every enemy up into a corner (which already takes away from the style and flash games like this are supposed to provide) prepare to ALWAYS be struck in the back mid combo. I constantly find myself hoping I could cancel my attack animations and black/counter like one would in the Batman Arkham series.
That was my biggest problem, but even without that, its brought down by many other factors such as bland AIs and limited movepool.
The game is definietly flashy, but they seem to have foregone basic mechanics in the process...

reviewText:
This is a good sword fighting game, better than most offerings in the Japanese Indie sale.

Gameplay is button-mashy but in a fun way, the standard suit-men enemies are fairly easy kills while the other enemies requre more strategy and skill. Bosses can be tough but chain-attacks and jumping are your friends here.
8/10

Storyline is simple but still somewhat compelling. However, there is very little lore to explain why the environments are what they are, how the sword came to be, and other various issues. This is somewhat of a problem since the main game is a 100% linear story.
5/10

Graphics are good. The characters are high-poly and high-res, and well done. The environments are not quite as good, being somewhat low-res. Enemies are well done. Optimization is better than many games, I can run it at 25-30fps with high (but not max) graphics on my gaming laptop (CPU i7-4510U, GPU R9 M275, RAM 8GB).
Overall Graphics are FAR beyond those of other games in the Japanese sale.
8/10

Overall this seems like the best game in the Japanese Indie sale, with fun gameplay and good graphics making up for a meh story. Though the game is somewhat short, it is engaging and fast-paced, so for $2.50 it is a great buy.
- 7.5/10 Overall -

reviewText:
Incredibly fun hack 'n' slash, very reminiscent of Devil May Cry; a good way to pass a great deal of time, but lacks an engaging storyline.

This game, to me at least, feels more like 'we designed a combat system, I wonder how well it works?' The answer to that is pretty clear: it's just awesome and so much fun to play with. Chaining together an potentially endless combo against truckloads of enemies garners immense enjoyment, and definite approval from me.
There is a fairly well-loaded upgrade path, and plenty of stages to cut through.
Three difficulty modes (though after learning the basics, you're going to want to play on Hard for maximum combos).
Achievements and Trading cards are a nice boon that I wasn't expecting, as well.

It also runs really smoothly and Misa's character model is amazingly high quality, especially for an anime-styled game.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Tedious button-mashy fodder battles on the same level, followed by hard boss fights where you can beat them with luck even if you lack the skill.

Why so: Not a particularly good brawler. The main characters may look nice and I'd expect them to have been the main selling point, but the gameplay itself is lacking.

The stages are all set on circular arenas with only the arena texture, the models surrounding the arena and the enemy waves varying. There aren't many different enemy times outside palette switched ones - cyborg(?) men in suits, large cyborgs, some cyborgs wielding a huge blade and some armored knight-lookalike. Sure, at least the two first have palette switches that denote different attacks, but the enemies are sorely lacking in variety. The phases before the level end boss are in general pushovers and I've managed to clear them (on normal difficulty) pretty well just mashing two buttons (sword slash and sword sheathing).

Killed enemies earn the player skill points which can be used to purchase new skills and upgrade old ones - not that there are all that many of them. I'd think Streets of Rage had more different moves than Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae has.

Whereas the fodders are way too easy, the bosses are in comparison very hard. Prepare to die by their hand several times - until you figure out that maxing out the sword sheathing and the special counter skill allows you to beat the enemies just by retrying the battle until you've managed to time your counters to enemy attacks the necessary 3-5 times to kill off the opponent. I still have trouble beating even the first two bosses, yet I've managed to complete the game (on normal difficulty).

On hard difficulty, the fodders become challenging as well and even the first level can cause trouble.

(EDITED: Added the note about hard difficulty and the fourth common enemy type.)

reviewText:
Man, this game is awesome! Already had it from Playism, but I bought it again here during the Steam Sale to support the devs and publisher. For 2 1/2 bucks, this is probably the best arcade experience you're going to find on modern PC.

It's just stylish battles in arenas, and there isn't a ton of enemy variety. The visuals are a little basic, but the character models - especially main character, Misa - look fantastic, as do the bigger enemies (not so much the guys in suits who look like Daft Punk imo).

That stylish arena battling, the real meat of the game? It has plenty of depth to provide for really  intense combat that ramps up pretty quickly. And it's just addicting failing > purchasing upgrades > trying again, just because you keep doing better and better. It's definitely one of those games where all the upgrades are hefty. You feel their impact immediately after hopping back into the game. The way upgrades should be.

I highly recommend this title. At $15, $10 or (like it is now) $2.49. As long as you dig intense combat and arcadey gameplay every now and then. This game does a fantastic job at providing this experience!

reviewText:
The most fun you can have with a game based off a hentai engine without taking your pants off. Unless that's your thing.

Short as hell, and a bit repetitive, but a fun little brawler that'll kill some time and look cute doing it too. It honestly gives off God Hand vibes, in a strange way, where it may not be the greatest looking thing in the world, and the story may be a bit dry, but god, the combat is so fun, even if it's simple and repetitive.

I got it at $2.50 during the summer sale, but I would've been willing to fork over ten for it if I knew it'd be this fun.

reviewText:
I went through several stages with this game. At first, I thought it was too mindless in the sense of carelessly and effortlessly hacking through wave after wave of minions. I figured that's all there was to it.
It wasn't until the second boss that I decided I hated the game. It felt unfair, unpolished and clumsy, and yet I found myself continuing to play, just to beat that damn second boss. Deep down, I knew it wasn't the gameplay that was clumsy; it was actually my shoddy skills.
Even though it took me countless tries to finally crush that second boss, and even though I actually threw the controller across the room several times, I kept coming back for more because at its core it's a damn fun game. And considering the size of the game and price, it does very well indeed.
Environments and enemies are limited, but again, considering the size it's easy to forgive. The story is substandard, but the meat of the gameplay and slicin' shitake up as a swordswoman in a nice outfit definitely makes up for it.
I recommend to those who are looking for a slash-em-up who isn't concerned with story or exploration.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The thing that I really like about this game, something I haven't seen said before, was how it progresses.

At the core, it's like a character action game (Devil May Cry, Beyonetta) set in a single arena. and at first it feels really limited. As you fight, string combos and clear waves you acquire points to spend on upgrades.  These upgrades are essential in advancing as the enemeis get increasingly tough and aggresive.

It's really hard to explain that classic Japanese sense of progression in games.  To start with a simple combo and end up stringing Stingers, Aerial Raves, sweeping attacks, power techs and charge slashes for 200+ hit combos.

reviewText: The first thing you should know about this game is that the game is 5 levels of 5 waves of enemies in a somewhat large circle arena. it is very repeatitive and there isnt alot of depth to it at all the story is very vague and simple also the skills dont take very long to max out. Now the reason that i would recommend this to anyone is the fact that its on sale currently and anyone who likes grindly japanese hack and slash games might enjoy this. The only game i can think of to compare it to that makes sense is Onechanbara as the combat is the same as well as how you unlock all of your abilites but thats about it. Everything in this game achievement wise can be completed in probably 6-8 hours if youre fast probably 10 if you take it slow and the replay value is very low after everything is done. If you enjoy games like Onechanbara and dont mind the doing the game over multiple times then it might be for you. but if you dont like to repeat the same fights over and over again you should probably avoid this game.

reviewText:
Japanese school girl wielding a demon katana goes mad so another Japanese school girl weilding a katana has to take her down.  Or something.

What may appear to be a shallow and lazy hack and slash type action game really isn't as bad as it might seem. At its core it shows a lot of premise, with fighting mechanics requiring precise timing to perform counters, dodging, blocking and looking for openings to counter attack. When your in the rhythm, it is rather enjoyable.

There are two main types of attack, fists and blade. Using your fists builds up your blade meter, whereas using your blade attacks slowly drains it, however you deal more damage that way. As you continue to do damage, you'll build up charge in your blade, when unleashed it will do further damage to bleeding enemies and recharge your health meter. Finally there is a holy"attack

reviewText:
To make this simple: The game is short. There are like 2 different stages that are set to 3 different daytimes. You face 5 enemy waves and then fight a boss. The graphics are solid but nothing special. The gameplay is kinda addictive and quiet fluent. Your char can wear like 5 different costumes. You get a feeling for speed and power combined with a sexy schoolgirl fighting her former classmate to purify her soul from demon spirits. After each stage you can use earned points to level up your skills or buy different clothes. I recommend you purchase this game when its on sale, not sure if 10 Euros are a reasonable bargain for you since you might get games with longer gamplay for that price. From the screenshots or Youtube videos the game looks way worse then it in fact is. The gameplay is very fun and has great potential. It reminds a little bit of Onimusha Warlords except you stick with the same sword and dont use elemental magic attacks. You can block attacks and use 2 different holy skills, nice kicks and beat the crap out of your enemies. Personally i like that developers did not try to put on a lightshow/ too many effects while using skill attacks because they are simple but looking great.
If you love samurai/ninja girls, hack and slash action and dont mind simple graphics, lack of content and a wider story this game might fill your break time.

Pros
+ Sexy girls
+ very good and addictiv gameplay
+ great feeling for power and speed
+ alternate costumes for your girl
+ Steam Achievements
+ developers put effort in the tutorial

Cons
- lack of content
- to few different stages with very simple graphics, nothing eyecatching except your character
- no multiplayer options
- very repeatative

recommended if you have not much time but enough money. Actually thumbs down for 10 €/$ offering basicly the lowest amount of content i ever experienced in a game so far but full thumbs up for gameplay experience.

reviewText:
As an avid action gamer out there, I'd recommend this game for several reasons. While it isn't perfect, it does provide thrilling battles to say the very least. With all panty shots aside i'll begin with the pros.

Pros:

- Price point is 10$ , as an indie title that will occupy you for at least 5 hours assuming you're not a fighting god it was good. I bought it on a sale which sold at $2.50. Unbeatable.
- The simple graphical style is colorful, I personally enjoy the character models.
- Easy to dive into and have fun with.
- Great to play in short peroids of time
- Contains a unique objective in its combat that is original so far.
- Detailed animations that flows nicely in its combat.

Cons:

- The story is lacking depth, practically nonexistant.
- An underwelming amount of content. (Looks back at its price point..)
- This isn't an adventure game, and will isolate players on a very small plain each stage.
- Gameplay gets repetitive quickly , yes this game has Beat em' up syndrome too.
- Some unlockable skills will probably be tossed in the player's trash bin of unused skills.

This game isn't for everyone, espeically those who find displeasure in a game with very strict mechanics. The use of Just Guard, Parry, and Counters in the game leaves players with a tiny window to use. Some hardcore action gamers would adapt to such, but it is difficult for people to make use of in general. Enemies attacks have priority over the player's, meaning if an enemy is attacking you aren't... unless you're some hotshot who is very good at judging the frames on attacks. While I personally see a lot of potential in its combat, it does not hold up as a novel or an exploration simulator it does make a fun, rewarding hack and slash game in my humble opinion. 7/10

reviewText:
This is getting immediately compared to DMC, when it's probably closer to the Onechanbara games: simplistic aesthetic, enclosed battle space and a battle system that, while possessing some speed and flair, lacks a certain finesse. And, well, sword-wielding females making up the main cast. MKH merely lacks them wearing all but a bikini and a ten gallon.

For a doujin title, its rather respectable. Again: for a doujin title. The interface has a bit of tack to it and, as I said, the battle system doesnt feel as tight as it could have been. You are tasked with fighting things before fighting things and then fighting maybe other things before getting a boss fight. Who you fight. My main gripe with said fighting was how easy it is to trigger annoying, weak, inappropriate and, most importantly, slow to recover attacks without meaning to do so. I feel like that could have been easily avoided by having them only activate with another independent button -- a lock-on, for example.

The difficulty isnt to be sniffed at either, bosses in particular will be quick to whittle away if you dont wise up quick enough and its surprisingly easy to get stunlocked by mere mobs (another negative trait shared with the Onechanbara series). With no means to cheese enemies via a ranged attack or super mode featuring health regen the latter battles on higher difficulties can become a test of mettle more than anything.

Its a good little slasher and a fine example of what can come out of Comiket, just dont go in expecting a perfectly polished experience.

reviewText:
You play as Misa a Blade Templar given the task of protecting the Demon Blade. Suzuka a close friend of yours has gotten her hands on the Demon Blade and is being corrupted by the powers it holds. The swrod manafests enemies and bosses through Suzuka's life force. So what do you do in turn? Fight your way through countless enemies and bosses in between stages.

There are 5 stages and 6 bosses. Between waves 1 - 5 of a stage you fight the indifferent mobs and at stage 6 you take on the boss. A lot of people complain about the difficulty which I do believe is there, for a while atleast. Once you get the patterns of the bosses down it gets easier. Similar to Dark Souls (don't kill me please) mixed with Ninja Gaiden. Really the hardest part of the game for me is the mobs at the higher difficulties. Even when you get their patterns down the sheer number of them at times can throw me off. Of coarse I plan to change that as I only have 10 hours in and am planning on getting all the emotes, backgrounds, badges, cards, and acheivements for the game.

The mechanics are pretty solid for me. I don't have much experience with this genre so I can't go in further details other than I find them very enjoyable. Fluid for the most part and plenty of defensive options that that are hard for me to get down and pat (i.e counter, flourish, just guard).

Story very linear but that doesn't matter to much with this kind of game. Cute girls, hard bosses, fluid combat, high combos. What's not to like about this game? How ever I have to say even if people like the Hack and Slash nature of the game it is VERY linear. You are set in an arena with changing back grounds after every boss fight. Enemy moddles are mostly the same but I don't mind that. For $2.50 or even the full price I would highly recommend this game, as I am enjoying it imensly. MIsa + Suzuka for life <3

reviewText: This is a no-frills action game. It's the bare essentials. It's simply a series of medium sized rooms filled with a variety of increasingly difficult enemies, minimal story and cutscenes, and one very fleshed-out moveset for your character. At first, the camera may seem annoying, but you'll get used to it quickly. It's a short game, fun without overstaying its welcome. If you like games like Devil May Cry or Bayonetta, it's really fun but missing many of the extra features found in most action games.

reviewText:
Mistsurgui Kamui Hikae is based on the rivalry between Musashi and kojiro.

The difficulty curve is there, Easy, Normal, Hard and Very Hard.

Easy for beginners and quite easy to complete
Normal for veterans you may get in trouble in some places but not too hard to complete
Hard, you need to unlock every weapon bonus as towards the end the bosses will give you trouble and you must learn to use just guards. If not, you cannot defeat the last boss at all, even in bleed state she will recover before you inflict any damage on her.

Very  hard, A NIGHTMARE mode, prepared to die lots as the enemies don't give you a chance to do anything, possible to do but you must use cheap out combos and even then, they can easily hit you while your doing it taking twice as much damage.

Graphics are nice, Gameplay is solid and story predictable however it's a fun game for an afternoon and serves it purpose, at least it doesn't last 45 seconds like many indie games these days.

reviewText:
STOP: This game may contain awesome.

There are many bad reviews piling up about the game most of which explain a lack of content and bad AI. which are quite false at the most part to be truthful, this game while being short is simple and effective and has a slight arcade feel to it, there doesn't need to be a brilliant story or thousands of different enemies for the game to be enjoyable, there are enough enemy types to give it variety and at harder difficulties the game truly becomes more about skill than button mashing. (although you might get lucky if you smash your keyboard hard enough).

The fighting mechanics are fluid as each of your attacks have a variety of branches at the end of each which allow you to hack and or smack your way into the triple digit combo's within 20 seconds, when you begin the game you are quite limited to not much with only various combo's, the unlock list isn't entirely technical and there isn't hundreds of complicated skills you need frustrate yourself over the complicated longer attacks are easy to execute and the game provides adequate tutorials to help you understand how to use them, (although some of the button symbols may confuse you).

so far I have sunk 10 hours into this game within 2 days and while it still has a few flaws which include very rare bugs which mean you can take 3/4 of the end bosses hp with one super attack on hard mode it is very polished, the mechanics are fluid and the attack methods are simple, Sure this is a game where you can mash on normal difficulty when the AI is a little slow and wont attack much, but as soon as you step into harder difficulties you'll really start to enjoy the game a lot more.

My score 7.5/10

IGN - IT HAS BOOBS 10/10 (probably, I don't have good resources)

reviewText:
TL;DR: Tedious button-mashy fodder battles on the same level, followed by hard boss fights where you can beat them with luck even if you lack the skill.

Why so: Not a particularly good brawler. The main characters may look nice and I'd expect them to have been the main selling point, but the gameplay itself is lacking.

The stages are all set on circular arenas with only the arena texture, the models surrounding the arena and the enemy waves varying. There aren't many different enemy times outside palette switched ones - cyborg(?) men in suits, large cyborgs, some cyborgs wielding a huge blade and some armored knight-lookalike. Sure, at least the two first have palette switches that denote different attacks, but the enemies are sorely lacking in variety. The phases before the level end boss are in general pushovers and I've managed to clear them (on normal difficulty) pretty well just mashing two buttons (sword slash and sword sheathing).

Killed enemies earn the player skill points which can be used to purchase new skills and upgrade old ones - not that there are all that many of them. I'd think Streets of Rage had more different moves than Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae has.

Whereas the fodders are way too easy, the bosses are in comparison very hard. Prepare to die by their hand several times - until you figure out that maxing out the sword sheathing and the special counter skill allows you to beat the enemies just by retrying the battle until you've managed to time your counters to enemy attacks the necessary 3-5 times to kill off the opponent. I still have trouble beating even the first two bosses, yet I've managed to complete the game (on normal difficulty).

On hard difficulty, the fodders become challenging as well and even the first level can cause trouble.

(EDITED: Added the note about hard difficulty and the fourth common enemy type.)

reviewText:
'The Smash Hit Action Game from Comic Market 84' is what the storefront would have you believe. And while the action is certainly white knuckle, with numerous combos and upgradeable skills, it's the intricately detailed and complex narrative that will have you talking about Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae long after the credits have rolled.

On the surface, it's about two teenage girls crossing swords in a battle to the death. But if you dig deep enough, you discover that the developers are actually commenting on the societal pressures that adolescent females in Japan must wade through each and every day. The struggle of Misa is one of innocence and purity versus the seductive lure of moral bankrupcy. Or perhaps....it is Suzuka the player should sympathize with. The girl that shuns forced traditions in a quest to establish her own identity.

No matter which way you look at it, this is the game that The Fullbright Company (Gone Home) wished they had created.

reviewText:
I started playing it now, and all i can say is: hoho, ha, ie, hoho, ha, ie, ie, hoho, ha.

Overall: 6.5/10
Graphics: 8/10
Story: 5/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Settings: 6/10

The game looks cool, but it's simple. You can't expect an AAA game. Even my woody pc can handle this on 20 FPS, but there's not too much options to graphics (if I could reduce the graphics, i would get like... 30-40 FPS). I found hard to play it with a keyboard. Controller is recommended. It's not impossible, but it's hard, so try to configure to be confortable for you (you can't configure to use the mouse, it's sad).

You are just looking for some action and beautiful characters to see their pantsus? That's the game. And the main character pants is black.

If you like animes, some fan service and some simple action, you can play this game! But it's not worth to buy it for full price. Wait for a sale.

If you are starting the game now, i recommend that you read this tutorial:
http://www.gamefaqs.com/pc/730164-mitsurugi-kamui-hikae/faqs/68362

The in-game tutorial is too simple. And try to finish it on the Easy mode first, to collect SP.
Hope you enjoy.

10/10 would Pantsu May Cry again.

reviewText:
Game: Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae
Genre: Action
Publisher/Developer: AGM Playism
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 40/100
Value Score: 4.0/10

• Story: 2/10
• Characters: 4/10
• GamePlay: 5/10
• Graphics: 5/10
• Sound: 3/10
• Music: 2/10
• Length: 2/10
• Replay Value: 3/10
• Player Value: 4/10

Pros
+Skill/ability system which can improve player's health, strength and other techniques/abilities. Increased via orbs received from defeated enemies.
+Multiple difficulty modes ranging from easy, normal and hard
+You can unlock costumes by beating the difficulty modes and unlocking via the ability menu using the orb points received from defeated enemies.

Cons
-Story is barebones, there's only about three or four cutscenes with minimal story scenes
-There are only two major characters with a bunch of generic enemies and bosses
-Not much on enemy variety, enemies come in same designs with different colors.
-Enemies come in 5 waves with a boss and some levels its only a boss battle
-Gameplay is repetitive in terms of attacks, you have a weak attack, strong attack, jump, guard, special attack and super attack which uses the katana gauge.
-Levels/stages are composed of arena type design with absolutely no exploration, puzzles or unique design.
-Gameplay UI and menus look poorly designed and low budget quality
-Environment visuals look inferior to the game models of the main characters. While the in game models for the main characters look like a 7th gen game model, the rest of the game looks like its from 5th or early 6th gen
-Sound effects are repetitive and keeps on repeating
-Music is forgettable and repetitive as well
-Game is very short - can be done within a hour and half to two hours depending on the difficulty and abilities (such as attack strength).
-Little replay value other than playing higher difficulties to unlock costumes

reviewText: Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae is a mediocre wave-based arena slash-em-up. Learning and leveling up skills requires hours of collecting in-game currency, but since the core gameplay is all about beating up the same 6 repeating enemy types, you might be too bored with that to notice that the game's a huge grindfest. Throw in some bizarre input commands for special moves, and you've got a recipe for a cumbersome game that is in no way worth the effort it requires. Even if you summon the superhuman amount of patience it takes to learn the intricacies of this game, there's nothing to do but Story Mode. The addition of something as simple as a survival mode could have redeemed this game by at least some measure, but the developer found it more appropriate to put that sort of effort into modeling perfectly heart-shaped butts. But hey, on the plus side...pantyshots.

reviewText:
+ Good graphics
+ Variety of combos
+ Stylish combat

- Locked resolution
- Locked at 30 FPS while on the arena
- Controls can be too complicated
- Little to no variation in enemy types
- The camera is hard to get used to
- Difficulty doesn't scale well
- Relies on short skirts and cleavage
- Too long a tutorial that doesn't help the complicated controls
- Gets too repetitive too soon
- One arena
- One song

Verdict: Maybe I'm just hard-ish to please, but MKH didn't do it for me. If you're looking to pass the time with a hack and slash designed specifically to pass the time, then it might please you. If you're looking for something that keeps your interest in mashing buttons, there are better options out there. The camera and the harsh difficulty scaling were the worst parts for me.

reviewText:
this game is in the same Genre as Onechanbara, but with less adult content in it.
i got to the first boss and died, this game is alot more difficult on normal than onechanbara berzerk difficulty (wii and xbox 360)
the game uses a bit of sexual appeal by using attractive characters, but doesnt really do anything lewd with them.
camera occasionally is an issue, but its not often and its seemingly a small oversight issue, i feel if they fixed it, it might become worse, ie camera automoves and you run where you DONT want to.)
your character is upgradable in battle which is VERY useful.
the games battles can feel repetative after a few waves, but when you fight waves of enemies in a brawler/hack and slash game that tends to always happen in the genre, but they throw in new enemies and new attack patterns to liven things up occasionally.
AI on normal seems a bit cautious, so it gives you a challenge if you keep pushing the same button over and over again, or aggressively attack everything in sight (or play the defense too)
the game plays well on a controller (id advise this STRONGLY)
the controlls are fluid, no screen tearing, the graphics look GREAT for an indie game.

id reccomend it if you like hack and slash games like onechanbara, Onimusha, god of war, bayonetta, darksiders, lolipop chainsaw, devil may cry, ninja gaiden or xblades.

start on easy so you can keep the bonuses/upgrades on normal, this game is kinda hard.

id personally give it a 78/100 if this was metacritic.
and for its price, thats not a bad deal :)

reviewText:
With only 5 stages, this is a short game that reminds me of older arcade titles.
There is barely any story to increase the length. That story is once again reminiscent of older arcade games, and is packed 100% with action anime tropes of course.

If you're good with brawlers you might finish it in two hours. Or even less.

However, beating the game unlocks harder difficulties which are so much harder, that it almost starts feeling like you're playing an entirely different game. (I am pretty sure I will not be able to beat the hardest setting actually XD).
There is also a grind quest to unlock new anime-classic costumes by earning points, it seems this quest seems to require around 10 game completions.

The conclusion is that these incentives to keep playing might be worthless to you, as they only matter if you like the game enough to keep playing after the first run.

So, would I recommend a two-hour-to-beat-once game?
Well, in this case, yes.

It's only two hours, but those are quite awesome and entertaining, especially if you're into anime.
The character, Misa, does't have a huge number of moves, but it's more about mastering them. All of the moves are useful and truly mandatory in harder difficulties. In my humble opinion, this is better design than having a huge moveset that you only use at 30% of its potential.

I know for sure that I had more fun with this game than with some hi-budget brawlers. I recommend it for anime and brawler fans especially. However, avoid like plague if you hate anime clichés.

And also : to truly enjoy this game, you NEED a controller. Preferably with twin analog sticks to have best control of Misa and the camera at the same time.

reviewText:
This is a pretty decent game that feels quite a bit like DMC, especially when playing as Vergil.

The campaign is very short, no more than 2 or so hours but that's not the point, the point is the action here. This game throws you into what is basically the bloody palace mode of DMC except the story is interwoven into it. The action is fairly decent and some of the attacks are pretty satisfying. The game is also quite hard even on normal, each enemy and boss will require a slightly different approach. You'll die repeatedly on the bosses if you don't adjust your play style accordingly.

There's unlockables and decent amount of upgrades to get as well so you'll most definitely be making use of the new game+ feature if you want to experience the combat system in its entirety.

The anction flows well and makes you feel good for keeping up a string of combos without taking a hit.

It's a game with a decent amount of passion and effort put into it however, do note that it honestly feels like a small piece of what could be a big game.

If you're just looking for some decent action and a game that you can come back to every now and then for some enjoyable combat this isn't a bad choice for 10 bucks, if it's on sale then stop reading this and get it, you certainly won't regret it as long as you know what you're getting into which is once again essentially the bloody palace mode of a DMC game with Vergil as the character.

Personally I hope to see this developer grow and possibly make something grander next time.

reviewText: A surprisingly good indie title. I was expecting it to be very technically flawed, bad programming and options. However, this game nails it in terms of quality compared to my expectations. Controls are fluent, combat is perfectly paced, the progression is straightforward. You can acquire all the moves very quickly, and upgrade by earning points during combat. I like how there are no complicated menus or RPG systems, it's all about the combat. You kill enemy, earn points, use points to upgrade. Furthermore, the game is very much pick-up-and-play. It may have a miniscule moves list, but the long combos and fast animations make for some satisfying brawler action. For a game that's 286 MB, the graphics aren't too shabby. The ability to save anytime, anywhere and return to the action without going through cumbersome menus or loading screens is commendable. This game distils hack and slash to its most core mechanics, adds its own little power-up twist so that it isn't a direct clone of other games, and puts you right in the action. It's literally all combat, there's no clutter at all. If you value simplicity as well as challenging difficulty - a game that relies solely on mechanics rather than fancy visuals or a story, this game is for you.\n\nHOWEVER, this is all assuming you can overlook the extremely difficult boss fights, where your timing has to be perfect and your health is so small and you do so little damage to the boss. If you just want to style, stick with DmC. If you don't mind frustrating boss fights, then this might be OK.

reviewText:
Horrible, horrible game.
Normal fights are ok, I like games where there isn't much of a story, or depths, just pure fun.
This game is not. Basically no story, no depth, only waves of enemies. And this game can ♥♥♥♥ up the only party it is meant to be good at.
The bossfights are just horrible. Undodgeable attacks, 360-noscope, millions of hp, but it can takes half of your hp away with one combo( which you can't dodge if you missed the first attack ).
This game is meant to give fun, but it's not fun at all. Don't get me wrong, I'm not usually bad at games, completed all the souls series, but this is just wrong. I know, there are strategies which you can kill the bosses, but if there is only 1 way to kill the boss( which is, run around, evade, evade, evade and million evade, then strike once, which takes the 0.0001% of it's hp ), then it's a bad game.
I really wanted to this game to be good, but unfortunately it isn't.

reviewText:
It has beautiful visuals and production qualities despite being a small ultra-under-the-radar game i would say. However, i can't help but to realize it is a rip-off of Onechanbara. There are some elements that shouts for further development, and remarkably, those elements make this game more fresh.
Fresh, i never said good

The game is quick and aggressive, has well made animation and good while somewhat repetitive score consisting of Rock music with both Western and Asian touch. The characters are not deep, but they are charming and weird by nature.......it is Japanese after all, and it isn't supposed to make any sense.

For some reason, and i dont know why, i enjoyed it more than the Bikini Zombie Slayers.
It is a mindless hack and slash game, but with qualities and artistic beauty.
But visuals are not the gameplay.

reviewText: An independently-produced Japanese game originally revealed at Comic Market 84, Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae focuses on high-speed arena-based action. Use lightning fast sword slashes, hand-to-hand attacks and mysterious ancient techniques to defeat wave after wave of demonic foes. Use skill points to learn new skills, upgrade your abilities, and take on brutal bosses. Weaken your enemies with vicious wounds, then sheathe your sword to finish them off with style. Employ hand-to-hand techniques to build your katana gauge, then cut deep with your divine blade.

reviewText:
Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae plays like a very simplified Dynasty Warriors where the main focus is just beating enemies up.  Using your sword skills, you fight rounds of enemies in an arena styled environment until you reach the boss of the level.  Repeat this again for more levels and that basically sums up the game.  There's a story but it's very simple and barely the focus of the game.  But the point of hack and slash games don't have to lie in story, it's in the combat although having a nice story is always a treat.

You start off with a very simple sword skillset and as you defeat more enemies you can unlock more skills or make your existing skills stronger.  Unfortunately the enemies aren't very varied, with many just being variations of the same types with more health and more damage with one or two new moves along with a different colored model.  This means that hitting enemies can start feeling like a chore as they become tankier and aren't as visually exciting.  The actual fun part of the swordplay lies in the counter system where perfectly timed counters deal massive damage to the enemies.  Because of the small window available for performing the counter, the first attempts will most likely end up in failure but once done correctly, it's immensely satisfying.  Even after finishing the game, I still find it fairly difficult to do.

Overall I would recommend this game with the caveat that you should like hack and slash games a lot and will find it more fun if you perform counters correctly.  Otherwise if you're looking for a Dynasty Warriors game, you won't find it in this.  Hopefully if the developers makes another game in the series, they'll expand the weapon types and the variety of enemies as well as create a larger, more interesting environment to fight in.

reviewText:
It's a hack and slash game reminiscent to games like Devil May Cry.

Pros:
Controls are pretty easy to get the hang of
Combos are strung together with ease
Upgrades are fairly cheap and can be obtained at any time

Cons:
Small stage sizes; akin to an area-fighter
It is a short game with only 5 actual stages
Boss battles almost lose the hack and slash combos in favor of baiting bosses into favorable/predictable patterns to allow for a few quick hits on them; As such, boss battles can take a while to complete before certain upgrades are obtained

All in all, it's not a bad way to spend a few hours if you have time to kill. It's fun, but it's also rather repetitive and nothing really game changing shows up by the end. Though it's probably not worth the full $9.99, it is definitely worth the sale price if you enjoy this kind of game.

reviewText:
This is a fun classic 3d hack and slash in the vain of Devil May Cry.  It is entirely focused on the combat, missions are about 5 waves of enemies on the same circular platform then a boss.  Controls are reponsive and a plethra of tightly timed counters makes for some allowances for quick paced combat which is not fully explored even on inferno (hardest difficulty unlocked after clearing hard and harder difficulty).  It contains all of the elements of a great hack and slash with nothing unique, but also nothing confusing or inhibitive.

Art style is clear, but uncreative.  Rather cynically I believe it was a choice mostly to expand the audience cheaply and effectively.  There is a story which is a stereo typically childhood friends turned cop vs robber.

Overall I would get this game if you are looking for another hack and slash or if you are interested if watching school girls  fighting with swords.

reviewText:
Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae is a 3rd person hack n slash/brawler/spectacle fighter/katana simulator with a name that almost no one outside of Japan can pronounce or even translate. So instead let’s just stick with pantsu may cry because you basically play as Vergil, the level format is similar to bloody palace and like the 4th game most of the budget and development time went into the combat system and nothing else.

The story is… there… occasionally, you play as Misa, a sword priestess cutting down waves of demons as she tries to catch her classmate who has been corrupted by the demon sword, that’s about all there is to it. There’s nothing interesting about the plot but it’s so simple and very rarely rears its head that it never becomes a detriment to the game.

The combat on the other hand is the sole reason to buy this game. Misa’s move set revolves entirely around her katana, her hand to hand attacks charge up a bar that allows her to use standard katana attacks as well as more powerful attacks with more range that have to be charged. The stand out superstar of this combat system however is her sheathing mechanic.

If you’ve watched enough anime in your life, you may be well aware of the cliché of sword fights where the finishing blow only appears once the winner sheaths their sword. Pantsu may cry translates this trope wonderfully into gameplay, if an enemy takes enough damage they start flashing red, Misa can then sheath her sword causing them to take more damage as well dropping health and spirit money that is used to upgrade her combat. As well as being as flashy as hell, it’s quite useful for staggering enemies as well as getting health without going through the effort of killing enemies, in fact enemies/bosses that would previously block Misa’s attacks without staggering can be stunned and juggled once they start flashing red which provides players an opportunity to go ballistic on an enemy that use to be a pain in their side.

There is no level design, you fight enemies in waves on a circular platform with an environment that occasionally change between fights, but just like the story that just means it doesn’t interfere. Most of the enemies and bosses are petty uninteresting with the exception of Suzuka, Misa’s classmate, who makes a great final boss with a fairly deep move set with attacks that have similar starting animations making them difficult to telegraph.

My one gripe with the combat is that there is no lock-on, so with no real method to focus on a single target, some of Misa’s attacks will go in a completely different direction than intended, also some attacks don’t string together, there are times when there’s that awkward pause between combos because the attack you inputted requires your katana to be sheathed, it’s an unnecessary nuance that convinces you to switch between hand to hand and katana attacks but it’s very minor and might not even be noticed on a 1st playthrough.

This game doesn’t have the depth of other hack n slash games such as Devil may cry and anything platinum makes, but it’s a £7 game that lasts around 4 hours and it’s great to play in between games. I hope this sheathing mechanic carries on to other games and I’ll gladly recommend it to anyone provided they’re aware that the combat is the only part of substance to the game.

reviewText:
If you like involved combo systems, tough but fair bosses, and slicing stuff up at high speeds, this game is definitely for you.

It's got great hack n slash action with a pretty deep combat system that does a good job letting you ramp you ramp your skill up over time. It's obviously made on a budget - the levels and graphics are pretty simple overall, and the game is quite short - but it's equally obvious that it was made with a lot of heart.

Hack n slash games aren't the most represented genre in games - only Devil May Cry and Ninja Gaiden are really worth mentioning in the mainstream space - so I'm super happy there's an indie entry that feels so true to the spirit of the genre.

reviewText:
The day at work has torn your heart and soul from your body. Your mouth is dry and you feel like you are slowly decaying as you are driving home. As the gate to the driveway is opening, you see a light at the end of the tunnel. Its a small light but its better than nothing. Seeing this light gives you a slither of energy to carry on. Everyone has that day, when you are too tired to play anything else and still crave to get your gaming gears grinding, even if its just for a few pathetic minutes. Can you relate to my day at work ? If your answer is yes then buy this game.

reviewText: What can I say about Schoolgirl May Cry? Maybe not the absolute best example of its genre, but I definitely got my money's worth and had a good time beating the crap out of robots and demons. I initially played it before it came out on Steam and was terrible at it and hit a wall fairly early on and gave up, but for whatever reason I gave it another shot when the Steam version came out. I learned the attack timings and combos better and had a lot more fun and did multiple runs through on different difficulty levels (hooray for New Game+), so it did something right to keep me going that long even though it's mostly just fighting waves of the same enemies in small arenas broken up by bosses. If you're into that sort of thing, check it out.

reviewText:
I have been FLOORED by this title.  A simple enough arcade game with a level of complexity somewhere between The Bouncer for PS2 and Devil May Cry 4, though requiring the precision and focus of an Onimusha game.  The gameplay is fast, frenetic and chaotic, while remaining mostly clean and not frustrating at all.

The story's lacklustre, sure; A presumed order of demon hunting templars houses an evil sword.  One of the students steals it, another pursues her.  End of story.  Don't go expecting much in the way of tears or feels and the like here folks, we're in it for one thing: Hardcore fantasy samurai action.

In terms of aesthetics, you play as a full thighed woman in a short skirt with a long sword against somewhat unimaginative enemies (Swordsmonster in a suit, cyborg swordmonster, almost Berserker from Fate/Stay Night, a knight), with a relatively uninspired soundtrack.  The characters voices only rarely venture towards annoying, which helps, and the attack sounds are alright enough.

Overall, for a game made by one dude and a coupla voice actresses, this is a helluva product.  I highly advise grabbing it if you get the oppurtunity.

reviewText: This one hell of a game. Of course as a doujin title it has some flaws and some of them may lead to frustration. Heroine may be late to react and your inputs to block or parry not always save you from enemy's hit. But overall that is very fun and addicting slasher with intersting combat system and tricky boss fights. Some may not like that all levels consist of nothing but arena but then again, that's a doujin game and level design takes some time and a lot of effort. The graphics are good, heroine's model looks fantastic and game runs smoothly even on low-tier PCs. Sound fits this game like a glove. Every hit and slash feels satisfying and music is decent. Highly recommend this game for every slasher enthusiast out there. Just don't let the lack of moves in the beginning deceive you: wait until you have enough points for upgrade and then real fun'll begin.

reviewText:
My initial impression of Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae was pretty dismal. Upon starting up the game, you are given a 2-minute blurb of generic short-skirt anime-babe save-the-world mumbo jumbo, then thrown into a fight with a bunch of samurai robots in business suits. Combat initially feels jerky and stilted, and the enemy AI is less than stellar. Mere moments into the action, my expectations were rapidly hitting rock-bottom, but I decided to play on. Fortunately, the game gets its act together soon enough.

Ignoring the story entirely, MKH is actually a competent, demanding arcade beat-em-up. Each stage places you in a circular arena, in which you must take down five waves of opponents, each more difficult than the last, capped with a boss monster. While combat initially feels sluggish, and the early enemies are laughable, both problems solve themselves in short order. You eventually start to grasp the nuances of the combat system, allowing a skilled player to duck and weave in and out of combat, hammering foes with punches and sword slices, leaving the opponents a bloody wreck, all without ever giving them a chance to strike back. Later foes block and even counter your attacks, brutally punishing you if you attempt to button mash and forcing you to fight cautiously. They also don't all look like murderous C-3P0s, which helps the aesthetic tremendously.

Opponents that have been damaged enough start flashing red, signifying that they are now more vulnerable to your basic attacks and are also capable of being instantly defeated through use of your cinematic sword-sheathing magic. Slaying enemies grants you SP, which you can spend to buy upgraded skills or better durability, as well as occasionally offering up big blobs of health. All in all, MKH is goofier than it intends to be, a bit repetitive, and doesn't exactly have the most complicated system in the world, but it's still a fun bit of slice-em-up action to burn an afternoon with.

reviewText:
When it comes down to it, this game is really exactly what it says it is: an arena brawler.  Like all brawlers, it follows the formula.   First, you're weak and it's overwhelming.  Then, as you get upgrades you start doing cool combos but still have some troubles with the bosses.  Finally, normal enemies are fodder for you and it's all about learning to react to each boss' telegraphed attacks.

The final difficulty is supposed to be painful but when you learn a certain holy technique you can exploit, you can just breeze through the game until the bosses.  Everything is one hit death so those final two bosses are quite the hurdle to get over.

Also, I'm biased because I love brawlers.  8/10

Also, when she runs you can see her panties.  And you run a lot.

reviewText: This game's horrible but it's definitely playable, feels like a robust minigame. (The game is pretty much DMC's Bloody Palace except with checkpoints.) It's literally 5 circle arenas with waves of a dozen different kinds of enemies along with 4 and a half bosses.  Also, its final difficulty is much like Dante Must Die difficulty except bosses still have a pretty significant amount of health. You eventually just have to learn how to use defensive manuevers and flourishes and suddenly the game's beyond easy, but until you get good you'll be tearing your hair out. If you don't like DMC style games you'll hate this and that would be totally understandable.\n\nDon't buy it unless it's under $5, or get it via the Humble Bundle along with a bunch of other stuff (it's available at this time.)

reviewText:
This game is like 137 MB, and you can tell.  Assets are reused all the time, and there's like five stages total.
And none of that is a bad thing.  Minimalism helps this game.

Controls are tight and combos are short, requiring chaining multiple types of combos into each other.  The bosses are all fun, and its a game that's actually very happy to be difficult.  None of it is cheap deaths.  Everything is avoidable and survivable.
So yes, it can be beaten in like two hours, but getting everything aside from the expensive costumes takes longer, all of it allowing you to do new tricks with a simple, but effective combo system based around switching quickly between attack types.  I just finished hard mode, and there's two more above that still for me to conquer.

This game knows what it wants to be; short, fun, and difficult.  The price tag reflects that, and it's a steal when on sale.

reviewText:
I knew nothing of this game until I saw it a couple months ago on the front page.  At first I didn't know what was going on but once you get the hang of the mechanics fun and do some upgrading it gets a bit enjoyable.  The best way to describe it is like a very, very watered down version of Ninja Gaiden 3 (xbox/ps3), kind of like a very early, early  prototype of that game.  DO NOT BUY AT FULL PRICE, it is not worth more than 2 or 3 dollars at most, as you will play it for a couple of hours, beat it and probably delete it off your computer or forget it's in your library.

If you want to know what it consists of:

You are placed in an arena-like area where you fight enemies in an enclosed space.  You defeat a certain number of waves" of enemies then boss fight -> cut scene -> repeat.  I'm having fun playing it but this game is really very limited in its execution and after a few upgrades you will plow through everything.  I recommend it only when it's on sale - if not you won't miss much.  It does have a silly charm to it - when playing it
date: I felt that with some more development
hoursPlayed: balance and variety
voteText: it could have been a more highly recommended game."

reviewText: Everything about this game is incredibly barebones. The sound design is sparce, the levels are always large, circular arenas, there's only a couple tracks of music in the game, the story is tacked on, and there's only a around 10-15 enemies. That being said, the one place that it isn't barebones is the actual combat. It's quick, frantic, and satisfying with the potential for an incredibly high skill cap if someone were to dedicate enough time to it. If you're looking for a a large game that you can sink dozens of hours into finding secrets and new areas, look somewhere else. However, if you're looking for a game with an insane amount of mechanical depth, buy this.\n\nI'll put it this way: If you'd consider paying 2.50-10 dollars for a version of DMC3/4 that only contained the Bloody Palace, then buy this immediately.

reviewText:
Story : This game have a very shallow storyline. If you like a game with deep storyline this game is not for you.

Gameplay : This is a basic Hack & Slash game where you have to fight waves of enemies before you fight the boss. You will face several type of enemies with different abilities and gain SP points when you kill the enemies to buy upgrade for you character. It is repetitive as you fight wave after wave but the challenge and fun is still there . The combat system is I think the most enjoyable feature of this game. Start form basic attack from the beginning then you will get new attack/skill when you upgrade your character. This new skill will add new way and combo for you to defeat you enemy. Some of this skill are very straightforward & some will required skill & practice to master it. This may make you want to replay the game on harder difficulty (or probably the same) just to test this new skill/move you unlock. The boss of this game can be annoying if you not pay enough attention to its movement and pattern. Pay enough attention it will be walk in a park.

Music & Voice Acting : Average…

Overall : It is a very fun game to play. Especially when you manage to unlock all upgrade for you character. I really recommend this game if you want to play a simple yet fun beat em up game and my rating of this game is 7/10

reviewText:
A Japanese arena style beat em' up game with heavy. Art-wise, it's fine. Liked the animations, the designs of the enemies have this neat robot theme, and the girls are cute even with the ecchi. Backgrounds and arenas are nothing to write home about. A big circle for the arena, backgrounds change but aren't that impressive.
The story barely exists, your friend has an evil sword and you want to save her. Done, whatever, moving on.
Controls are finicky, playing this game on a mouse and keyboard is impossible. It's designed for a controller and nothing but. The tutorial and interface are also a problem, they tell you to hit certain attacks without button prompts.

All that aside, when you do have a controller and know how things work, things get fun. The system allows for a lot of insane combos and bouncing around. You can block, but it's actually better not to since it kills the flow. Bosses are insanely hard and become a lot of fun if that sort of challenge doesn't aggrevate you. Enemies start off from peons you step on to to behemoths that pose a fair challenge in their own right. Difficulty spikes up quickly enough to keep things interesting.

For me, the buy was worth it based on the art and gameplay. It doesn't price itself too high so it's worth it if you like these sorts of games. Getting it on sale is fine, but you can't argue with an asking price of $15 for this level of challenge.

reviewText:
Long story short: Beautiful.

Long story: Graphics are nice, one of the smoothest combat systems I've tinkered with. Difficulties ranging from easy to very hard. The music is good. Almost every sound is important, from hearing footsteps of background enemies to the cries of your antagonist. Sometimes the camera angle goes bonkers but, that in no way effects the overall gameplay. Moves flow like water. Can upgrade your attacks or gain new ones. Earn points to buy costumes. Even after you beat one level of difficulty, there's even higher, challenging ones. The game makes you want to try the different difficulties to test your own skill and trust me, it gets harder. Great repeatability. Still working on very hard mode to be honest lol. It's a game I chose to get at the last second and I have no regrets.

Grade: A

reviewText:
This game consists mainly of fighting several enemies at a time inside a confined enclosure that has absolutely no bits of scenery except a couple of fake looking buildings in the background. The enemies in the game consist of a guy with a sword, a giant robot guy, and a giant demon guy.

The way they keep the game from running out of content was to recolor the enemies and give them an ever so slightly different skillset. The control system for this game has the camera controlled by the keyboard, and the attack skills have absolutely no variation besides the original two or three swipes.

The skills themselves are completely broken, as you can kick enemies up in the air and kick them back down while staying invicible. Other skills simply hit every enemy around you, stunning them and slowly killing them.

Overall the gameplay is boring and repetitive, and only a Call of Duty player could ever find it even slightly amusing
0/10 Would play again

reviewText: I picked up Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae on a complete whim, it was very cheap and looked like alot of fun. Whilst it makes little sense at times, it really is good fun. reviewText: Really fun Hack n' Slash game, similar in fighting style to Devil May Cry.  The game is pretty short, but it might take a few tries to finish the boss fights.  The bosses telegraph some of their attacks too fast for you to react in time to block or dodge them.  You'll need a lot of patience and good reaction time to get to the end.  When you kill enemies you get SP which can be used to level up your attacks and upgrade your skills which will make fighting bosses a bit easier.  Even after you beat the game, you can go back for new game+ and finish upgrading your moves, or if you want you can save up 100,000 SP to get the alternate costumes for your character.  The game has good replay value, but I guess I don't feel like playing for 100 additional hours to do that, so I will never see them.

reviewText:
If you like involved combo systems, tough but fair bosses, and slicing stuff up at high speeds, this game is definitely for you.

It's got great hack n slash action with a pretty deep combat system that does a good job letting you ramp you ramp your skill up over time. It's obviously made on a budget - the levels and graphics are pretty simple overall, and the game is quite short - but it's equally obvious that it was made with a lot of heart.

Hack n slash games aren't the most represented genre in games - only Devil May Cry and Ninja Gaiden are really worth mentioning in the mainstream space - so I'm super happy there's an indie entry that feels so true to the spirit of the genre.

reviewText:
The day at work has torn your heart and soul from your body. Your mouth is dry and you feel like you are slowly decaying as you are driving home. As the gate to the driveway is opening, you see a light at the end of the tunnel. Its a small light but its better than nothing. Seeing this light gives you a slither of energy to carry on. Only barely making it to the kettle to shove caffine down your throat, crawling over to your room in the back to finally switch on the PC.
You have one hour, make the most of it.

Everyone has that day, when you are too tired to play anything else and still crave to get your gaming gears grinding, even if its just for a few pathetic minutes. Can you relate to my day at work ? If your answer is yes then buy this game.

reviewText:
A pretty straight-forward arena-based hack-and-slash. You earn points from beating enemies that you can use to buy new skills and upgrade current ones, or unlock outfits.

Pros:
- Good variety of moves and combos
- Easy, medium and hard difficulties, with very hard and inferno modes unlockable
- Very hard and especially inferno modes are challenging
- High skill cap, counters and flourishes are hard to pull off
- Can play for 5 minutes or an hour, very easy to pick up and put down again
- Unlockable outfits

Cons:

- Can feel repetitive, especially on easy and normal difficulty where there's little challenge and mostly button mashing
- Enemies have just a little too much health on very hard mode
- Camera could be better, you can't always see every enemy which can be a pain in the butt on higher difficulties
- Cliche story that kinda sucks, also there's hardly any of it
- No reward for completing inferno, besides an achievement

Overall I really enjoyed the game, if you like hack-and-slash gameplay like in Dynasty Warriors, give this a try. Also inferno mode is a ♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
This is a fun classic 3d hack and slash in the vain of Devil May Cry.  It is entirely focused on the combat, missions are about 5 waves of enemies on the same circular platform then a boss.  Controls are reponsive and a plethra of tightly timed counters makes for some allowances for quick paced combat which is not fully explored even on inferno (hardest difficulty unlocked after clearing hard and harder difficulty).  It contains all of the elements of a great hack and slash with nothing unique, but also nothing confusing or inhibitive.

Art style is clear, but uncreative.  Rather cynically I believe it was a choice mostly to expand the audience cheaply and effectively.  There is a story which is a stereo typically childhood friends turned cop vs robber.

Overall I would get this game if you are looking for another hack and slash or if you are interested if watching school girls  fighting with swords.

reviewText:
Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae is a 3rd person hack n slash/brawler/spectacle fighter/katana simulator with a name that almost no one outside of Japan can pronounce or even translate. So instead let’s just stick with pantsu may cry because you basically play as Vergil, the level format is similar to bloody palace and like the 4th game most of the budget and development time went into the combat system and nothing else.

The story is… there… occasionally, you play as Misa, a sword priestess cutting down waves of demons as she tries to catch her classmate who has been corrupted by the demon sword, that’s about all there is to it. There’s nothing interesting about the plot but it’s so simple and very rarely rears its head that it never becomes a detriment to the game.

The combat on the other hand is the sole reason to buy this game. Misa’s move set revolves entirely around her katana, her hand to hand attacks charge up a bar that allows her to use standard katana attacks as well as more powerful attacks with more range that have to be charged. The stand out superstar of this combat system however is her sheathing mechanic.

If you’ve watched enough anime in your life, you may be well aware of the cliché of sword fights where the finishing blow only appears once the winner sheaths their sword. Pantsu may cry translates this trope wonderfully into gameplay, if an enemy takes enough damage they start flashing red, Misa can then sheath her sword causing them to take more damage as well dropping health and spirit money that is used to upgrade her combat. As well as being as flashy as hell, it’s quite useful for staggering enemies as well as getting health without going through the effort of killing enemies, in fact enemies/bosses that would previously block Misa’s attacks without staggering can be stunned and juggled once they start flashing red which provides players an opportunity to go ballistic on an enemy that use to be a pain in their side.

There is no level design, you fight enemies in waves on a circular platform with an environment that occasionally change between fights, but just like the story that just means it doesn’t interfere. Most of the enemies and bosses are petty uninteresting with the exception of Suzuka, Misa’s classmate, who makes a great final boss with a fairly deep move set with attacks that have similar starting animations making them difficult to telegraph.

My one gripe with the combat is that there is no lock-on, so with no real method to focus on a single target, some of Misa’s attacks will go in a completely different direction than intended, also some attacks don’t string together, there are times when there’s that awkward pause between combos because the attack you inputted requires your katana to be sheathed, it’s an unnecessary nuance that convinces you to switch between hand to hand and katana attacks but it’s very minor and might not even be noticed on a 1st playthrough.

This game doesn’t have the depth of other hack n slash games such as Devil may cry and anything platinum makes, but it’s a £7 game that lasts around 4 hours and it’s great to play in between games. I hope this sheathing mechanic carries on to other games and I’ll gladly recommend it to anyone provided they’re aware that the combat is the only part of substance to the game.

Things to remember:

• Just Guard often.
• Quickly Guard often to string together larger combos.
• Upgrade points can be spent at any time.

reviewText:
This game consists mainly of fighting several enemies at a time inside a confined enclosure that has absolutely no bits of scenery except a couple of fake looking buildings in the background. The enemies in the game consist of a guy with a sword, a giant robot guy, and a giant demon guy.

The way they keep the game from running out of content was to recolor the enemies and give them an ever so slightly different skillset. The control system for this game has the camera controlled by the keyboard, and the attack skills have absolutely no variation besides the original two or three swipes.

The skills themselves are completely broken, as you can kick enemies up in the air and kick them back down while staying invicible. Other skills simply hit every enemy around you, stunning them and slowly killing them.

Overall the gameplay is boring and repetitive, and only a Call of Duty player could ever find it even slightly amusing
0/10 Would play again

reviewText:
A Japanese arena style beat em' up game with heavy. Art-wise, it's fine. Liked the animations, the designs of the enemies have this neat robot theme, and the girls are cute even with the ecchi. Backgrounds and arenas are nothing to write home about. A big circle for the arena, backgrounds change but aren't that impressive.
The story barely exists, your friend has an evil sword and you want to save her. Done, whatever, moving on.
Controls are finicky, playing this game on a mouse and keyboard is impossible. It's designed for a controller and nothing but. The tutorial and interface are also a problem, they tell you to hit certain attacks without button prompts.

All that aside, when you do have a controller and know how things work, things get fun. The system allows for a lot of insane combos and bouncing around. You can block, but it's actually better not to since it kills the flow. Bosses are insanely hard and become a lot of fun if that sort of challenge doesn't aggrevate you. Enemies start off from peons you step on to to behemoths that pose a fair challenge in their own right. Difficulty spikes up quickly enough to keep things interesting.

For me, the buy was worth it based on the art and gameplay. It doesn't price itself too high so it's worth it if you like these sorts of games. Getting it on sale is fine, but you can't argue with an asking price of $15 for this level of challenge.

reviewText: Got this game on Steam Sale on June 2014 and all that I can say is that it is a very good game for $2.50 and for being a indie game. recommended:
dodge and use crowd control in order to survive every wave also the recommended is to start on Easy and collect all the skills on your first walk-through the move to normal when you have all the upgrades.

The game also change the amount of enemies that you get in each wave if you select Normal or Hard and on Hard you will fight more aggressive enemies and the bosses have one "super move" available too.

Overall a good game and worth even a price of $10 or $15 but for $2.50 it was a really good deal!"

reviewText: This game is about as Japanese as it gets, well atleast before you get into Hentia. The Options menu even feels like it has a Japanese accent. If you're looking for story, this probably isn't the best game for that. If you're looking for a Hack'N'Slash, this is a great game. It places you in a circular areana, facing waves of enemies. A key part is making the enemies bleed as that affects how they fight. It's pretty hard at first, and the tuturial doesn't help too much. You can figure it out on your own, it's just going to take a bit. Overall this is a fun game if you like Hack'N'Slash games, but if you aren't quite into those I would defenitly steer clear of this one.

reviewText:
If you like hack n slash games with anime girls this is potentially the title for you.

Pros:
-I found buying new moves with XP to create my own fighting stlye very enjoyable
-The controls (xbox pad) were responsive, which is great because I've often seen games advertise full controller support only to have lackluster control schemes and no remapping options or any of a host of problems

Cons:
-I don't remember the story, something about girls and swords. Well what do you expect from a hack n slash about anime girls?
-Extremely short campaign. I've beaten the whole thing multiple times on the hardest difficulty and I still only have 2 hours logged. My first play was about 45 minutes in length
-A bit too easy. Even on the hardest difficulty few if any of the enemies pose a serious threat to a skilled player
-Very small arenas" for each stage rather than a full level. In each of these arenas designed to look like some location or another you see small snippets of the story in a cutscene
date: fight a few waves of enemies and then fight a boss. Very simple; but not necessarily a bad thing.\n\nIn summation: get it if you enjoy hacking and slashing
recommended: but wait until its on super sale
hoursPlayed: like 50-75% off would be fine."

reviewText: I'm A huge fan of ninja gaiden like action games...Like I've been at the top of the leader boards in the ninja gaiden black(xbox) and sigma 2(ps3). That being said I love hack and slash games with a decent combat system. If you are the type of fan who is super into games like Bayonetta or Ninja giaden specifically for the combat then you might like this game. It has a simple time based/reflex based combat system where you simply combo enemies repeatdily and time your parries and counter attacks as you see them coming. The game rewards you for not getting hit by giving you charges for your holy attacks and red orbs when you kill enemies. All that being said I only recommend this game to pure action hack and slash enthusiast since this game is just basically you in a arena killing enemies in numerous waves until you get to the boss. There is no platforming or puzzles or any other basic extra type of game play you'd expect in a standard hack and slash game...just combat in a room/area. So far I've beaten 3 bosses. I've enjoyed the game for what it is and personally I think  Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae is better than DmC or ninja gaiden 3 despite it being a barebones and simple action game.

reviewText:
- there is no tutorial
- the icons for the buttons match neither xbox nor playstation layout

- at the start the only combos you can performe are all mash the same button until the animation stops"

in conclusion

reviewText:
What can I say? For it's price, this game is quite good. Especially if you picked it up during the Summer Sale, as I did.

The graphics are rather good, especially since the game is 300Mb in size or so. Unfortunately, there isn't much of a variety when it comes to enemy and level designs. Basically the levels are sealed arenas like the Bloody Palace mode in Devil May Cry games.

The soundtrack is ok, but it has only 3 songs and they get quite repetitive. After two hours I just switched the music off and went to my Metal Gear Risng and Devil May Cry soundtrack folders.

Gameplay and controls... controls are quite responsive and fast, you won't feel some sloppy reactions to your inputs. The gameplay is rather repetitve. No, you have different moves and techniques like blocking at the last moment to block a very powerful attack (similar to Royal Guard style from DMC3), different cancels, launcher attacks, dodges, but after finding a combo that is most effective for your playing style it all becomes quite repetitve.

All in all... it feels incomplete, like a tech demo. It's fun, don't get me wrong, but I would love to see these gameplay mechanics to be expanded in a more complete" character action game.

Oh

reviewText:
Pretty solid hack 'n' slash

It has a good number of combos and cancels. The upgrade system is well done and by the second play though you should have everything. Nice number alternate costumes. The game is rather short though but without ugrades can be difficult. Maxed stats make the game too easy however, even on the hardest difficulty.

The story is rather chill with a very simple concept and cool characters but practiaclly non-existant.

8/10 -> would like the game to be expanded or recieve a sequel
